title: For Sale/Trade:  Oak Leaf 12ga Shotgun, Deer gun
postcontent:
This is an old 12ga single shot, brand is Oak Leaf, Walden, NY.  Patent date is August 12, 1913.  For its age it is in nice condition, it is a user, not a museum piece.  Someone has cut the barrel and added a select-a-choke/compensator made by Polly choke Co. of Hartford Conn.  Settings on the choke are: ImpCly, Mod, ImpMod, Full, XtraFull, and Slug.  It has a single bead sight on the compensator.  Barrel length is 20" to the bottom of the choke/comp, 24" total.
I have shot this and it functions as it should.  Overall it is a nice compact lightweight package perfect for carrying through the woods or to keep in the truck.

Taurus 24/7 OSS Tactical in .40 5.25in barrel 15+1
The 24/7 Tactical was developed to compete for a military contract against the top names in gun making. This model was in the finals when the military canceled the contract. This full size model is no longer made and has been replaced with the G2 model with only a 4in barrel. This is a great weapon with several unique features plus Taurus lifetime warrenty. 5.25in barrel, DA/SA Striker Fire system. Decocker/Safety and "second strike" capability similar to Walther's. title: For Sale/Trade:  Smith & Wesson 19-3 Nickel 2.5" revolver (1971 issue)
postcontent:
Smith & Wesson Model 19-3 .38/.357 Magnum, with a early 3K9XXX serial number from 1971. Has a 2.5" Pinned barrel & recessed cylinder chambers. Beautiful case hardening in trigger and firing pin mounted hammer. This is a very rare nickel variation with matching numbers light gray box, grips are #'s matching as well. title: For Sale/Trade:  COP 357 (4-barrel derringer)
postcontent:
Video of it firing: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vTlZbAmev8U

The COP (short for Compact Off-duty Police) 357 was designed by Robert Hillberg 1981 and manufactured by COP Inc. from 1981 until at least 1983. It is a 4-barrel derringer chambered in .357 Magnum, and utilizes a clockwise-rotating firing pin mechanism to fire each round individually. A very space-age design, the COP has been featured in prominent science-fiction films and television shows, to include Blade Runner, The Matrix Reloaded, Battlestar Galactica, and Stargate SG-1.

Comes with original box and paperwork.

Read more about this gun here: http://www.mythicarmory.com/cop-357--mini-cop.html

The Drozd is made in Russia by IZH-Baikal. It uses a standard 12-gram CO2 cartridge and six AA batteries. There are three switches to operate the unique select-fire mechanism. The first one turns on the gun. The second one selects the firing mode: semi-auto (one shot with each pull of the trigger), three-round burst (full-auto) or six-round burst (full-auto). The third switch controls the burst rate: 300 rounds per minute, 450 rounds per minute or 600 rounds per minute

title: For Sale:  Gwinn Bushmaster Assault Rifle - Prototype AR-15
postcontent:
This classic Gwinn AR-15 prototype rifle came in with several other guns that were displayed at the Evergreen Aviation Museum in Oregon. Several types and configurations of this rifle can be found for sale (including pistols), but rarely in this condition and with the painted-wooden stock option. It also features a stamped-steel receiver like most of the bullpup rifles produced by Gwinn.

The stamped-steel upper receiver and aluminum billet lower receiver are in great condition, with a little sign of tarnish on the upper. The internals look clean, and the barrel bore is shiny and clean. Some scuff marks can be found here-and-there - most likely from display and use. Wood is also in excellent shape with little sign of wear or use - just a few scuffs here-and-there. 

The side-cocking charging handle work smooth - but is a little wobbly. Probably designed that way to ensure it won't bind during recip.

It's a fully insulated little house but does not have plumbing, it is all electric and has a small space heater that more than enough to provide heat in the winter and a 5,000 BTU air conditioner that does a great job of keeping it nice a cool. The USP (Universelle Selbstladepistole or "universal self-loading pistol") is a semi-automatic pistol developed in Germany by Heckler & Koch GmbH (H&K) of Oberndorf am Neckar as a replacement for the P7 series of handguns.
Design work on a new family of pistols commenced in September 1989 focused primarily on the U.S. commercial and law enforcement markets. In 1991, USP prototypes participated in rigorous testing alongside H&K's entry in the Offensive Handgun Weapon System (OHWS) program requested by the U.S. Special Operations Command (USSOCOM) and which would later result in the Mk 23 Mod 0. The USP prototypes were then refined in 1992, based on input from the OHWS trials, and the design was finalized in December of the same year. The USP was formally introduced in January 1993

postcontent:
Kel-Tec PMR-30 with Titanium Cerakote Aluminum Frame. Comes with 1 30rd magazine.

The PMR-30 is a light weight, full size pistol chambered for the flat-shooting .22Magnum cartridge (.22WMR). The PMR-30 operates on a unique hybrid blowback/locked-breech system. This operation system allows for the use of a wide variety of ammunition as it seamlessly adjusts between locked breech and blowback operation, depending on the pressure of the cartridge. It uses a double stack magazine of a new design that holds 30 rounds and fits completely in the grip of the pistol. The trigger is a crisp single action with an over-travel stop. The manual safety is a thumb activated ambidextrous safety lever (up for SAFE, down for FIRE). The slide locks back after the last shot and a manual slide lock lever is also provided. The light, crisp trigger pull and fiber optic sights make the PMR-30 ideal for target shooting and hunting small game.

Slide and barrel are 4140 steel, frame is 7075 aluminum. Grip, slide cover, trigger, mag release, and safety levers are glass reinforced Nylon (Zytel), much like other Kel-Tec Pistols. Magazine is Also Zytel and holds 30 rounds, with round count ports. Other features include: dual opposing extractors for reliability, heel magazine release to aid in magazine retention, dovetailed aluminum front sight, Picatinny accessory rail under the barrel, Urethane recoil buffer, captive coaxial recoil springs. PMR30 disassembles for cleaning by removal of a single pin.

This has a focusable green laser which effectively gives you a variable illumination area (similar to night vision, except the light beam is visible to animals), and has a built-in red aiming laser for daytime use. You probably have noticed these are really hard to find in 7mm-08, but it's (my opinion) about the neatest caliber for AR-10-type rifles for ranges out to 800-900 meters. Bolt carrier is nickle-boron and stock is standard A2. (Choice of aftermarket stocks is too variable and personal, so I went with the standard, very stable stock). Scope is Millett TRS-1 with mildot reticle and 0.1 mil. clicks. Sunshade is pictured installed. If you don't need the sunshade, the scope appears much smaller. Full-float handguard and Harris-type bipod. Comes with three 20-round ASCs and the original DPMS magazine
